par.span: REGULATORY OVERVIEW
This module covers the regulatory part of the Hazardous
Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) training. It includes:

ul.li: Lesson 1: OSHA and The HAZWOPER Standard
Lesson 2: Hazard Communication
Lesson 3: NFPA System and DOT Labels

par.span: By the end of this module, you will be able to:

ul.li: Define OSHA and explain why it is important;
Define HAZWOPER and explain who is affected by these regulations;
Explain why OSHA developed the Hazard Communication Standard (HCS);
Describe the Globally Harmonized System (GHS) of Classification and Labelling of Chemicals and its importance;
List required labeling elements under the GHS system;

Explain the four parts of the NFPA labelling system;
List the various Department of Transportation (DOT) chemical hazard classes.

lesson.name: Lesson 1: OSHA AND THE HAZWOPER STANDARD

par.span: OSHA AND THE HAZWOPER STANDARD

topics.name: The Occupational Safety and Health (OSH) Act

par.span: On December 29, 1970, President Nixon signed the Occupational Safety
and Health Act of 1970 (OSH Act) into law, establishing the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA).
It is a national public health agency which is dedicated to protecting America’s workers
so that no worker should have to choose between their life and job.
The purpose of the OSH Act is:
“to assure so far as possible every working man and woman in the Nation safe and healthful working conditions and to preserve our human resources."
Click here for more information on the OSH Act

topics.name: Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER)

par.span: The dumping of hazardous substances poses a significant threat and is a serious safety and health problem that continues to endanger
the lives of humans and animals and the quality of their environment. The seriousness of this issue has led to OSHA issuing the HAZWOPER Standard.
HAZWOPER stands for Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response. HAZWOPER regulations are covered under the Title
29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), part 1910.120.
This standard was issued to protect the health and safety of those working at waste sites and to help them handle hazardous substances safely and effectively.
OSHA requires HAZWOPER training for anyone who is:

ul.li: Cleaning up hazardous waste sites;
Working with hazardous waste at treatment, storage, and disposal sites; or
Responding to emergencies concerning hazardous material releases.

par.span: The HAZWOPER regulation
contains 17 different sections. There are also five appendices, Appendix A to Appendix E, that help employers and employees comply with the regulations of this standard.
Under federal code, Title 29 CFR 1910.120 establishes Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response regulations concerning:

ol.li: Engineering Controls, Work Practices, and Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) for Protection of employees
Emergency Response at an Uncontrolled Hazardous Waste Site
Emergency Response to Hazardous Substance Releases

par.span: Click here to view examples of scope and application of the HAZWOPER standard

ul.li: Scope, Application, and Definitions
Section (a) covers the scope and application of this standard.
Safety and Health Program
Site Characterization and Analysis
Site Control
Training (General Site Remediation)
Medical Surveillance
Engineering Controls, Work Practices, and Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) for Protection of employees
Monitoring
Information Programs
Handling Drums and Containers
Decontamination
Emergency Response at an Uncontrolled Hazardous Waste Site
Illumination
Sanitation at Temporary Workplaces
New Technology Programs
Sections (b) to (o) of the standard regulates operations where employees are engaged in the cleanup of uncontrolled hazardous waste sites.
Section (e) of the HAZWOPER regulation applies to general site workers, and this is by far the largest number of people requiring the HAZWOPER training.
Certain Operations Conducted Under RCRA
Section (p) covers those employees who are engaged in treatment, storage and disposal (TSD) facility operations for hazardous waste.
Emergency Response to Hazardous Substance Releases
Section (q) covers emergency responders for releases of hazardous substances without regard to the location of the hazard.

par.span: There are five appendices to the HAZWOPER regulation that assist employers
and employees in complying with the provisions of this standard. These include:

li.a: Appendix A: Personal protective clothing test methods

ul.li: Appendix B: General description and discussion of the levels of protection and protective gear
Appendix C: Compliance guidelines
Appendix D: References
Appendix E: Training curriculum guidelines

par.span: HAZWOPER regulations apply in the following work areas:
Clean-up operations required by a government body, whether local, state, federal or other, involving hazardous substances at uncontrolled hazardous waste sites.
Corrective measures and clean- up activities at sites covered by the 1976 Resource Conservation and Recovery Act( RCRA).
Voluntary clean-up operations at uncontrolled hazardous waste sites by local, state and federal government bodies.
Operations involving hazardous waste carried out in treatment, storage or disposal facilities (TSD), by agencies in accordance with the EPA Regulation.
Emergency response operations for the release of, or substantial threats of the release of, hazardous substances without regard to the location of the hazard.
There are several types of HAZWOPER training for the general site worker depending on your job type and experience:

ul.li: 40-hour training
24-hour training
8-hour annual refresher

par.span: The 40-hour course, which you are just beginning, is intended for workers who perform activities that could expose or potentially expose them
to hazardous substances above the Permissible Exposure Limit (PEL) established by OSHA. These individuals usually require the use of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE).
The 24-hour HAZWOPER course is for workers who have a temporary or short-term assignment at a HAZWOPER site and will not be exposed to hazardous materials
above the PEL established by OSHA, and therefore will not require respiratory protection. These individuals do not require the use of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE).
The 8-hour annual refresher course is required for both the 24-hour and 40-hour certified individuals to re-emphasize the initial training and to update workers on any new policies or procedures.
The level of training provided to general site workers should be consistent with their job function and responsibilities.
General site workers represent the largest group of people who require the HAZWOPER training. According to OSHA, training should include instruction in the following areas:

ul.li: Site Safety and Health plan;
Safe work practices;
Expected nature of hazards at the worksite;
Sampling and monitoring procedures;
Safe and effective use of personal protective equipment (PPE);
Employee rights and responsibilities; and
Site emergencies, rescue and evacuation procedures.

topics.name: The HAZWOPER Standard and Other Regulations

par.span: A number of work tasks performed at a HAZWOPER work-site may over lap and cross over into other areas regulated by OSHA.
All of these areas are related to HAZWOPER and will be discussed in detail in the modules that follow.
For example Bloodborne Pathogens Standard (29 CFR 1020.1030), Respiratory Protection Standard (29 CFR 1020.134) etc.
Click here for more information on OSHA’s Regulations
Under the OSH Act, employers have the following responsibilities:

ul.li: Conspicuously display the OSHA’s Job Safety and Health poster.
Inform workers about chemical hazards through training, labels, alarms, color-coded systems, chemical information sheets and various other methods.
Maintain records of work-related injuries and illnesses with accuracy.
Perform tests in the workplace that are required by OSHA standards, such as air sampling.
Provide required personal protective equipment (PPE) at no cost to employee.
Provide medical tests required by OSHA standards.
Notify OSHA within 8 hours of a workplace fatality.
Not retaliate against workers for using their rights as given to them under this law; including their right to report a work-related complaint.

par.span: Under the OSH Act employees have the following rights:

ul.li: File a confidential complaint with OSHA for workplace inspection.
Receive information and training related to hazards, methods to prevent harm, and OSHA standards that apply to their workplace.
Be given training that must be done in a language that is easy for the workers to understand.
Receive information about work-related injuries and illnesses that occur in their workplace.
Receive the results obtained from tests and monitoring done to find and measure hazards in their workplace.
Receive copies of their work-related medical records.
Be a part of an OSHA inspection and speak with the inspector confidentially.
File a complaint with OSHA in case of any retaliation by their employer for acting as a “whistleblower”.

par.span: Employees also have certain responsibilities when it comes to workplace safety,
even though OSHA does not cite employees for violations. The employees have the following responsibilities:

ul.li: Carefully read the OSHA Job Safety and Health poster.
Follow the workplace safety rules and use the required personal protective equipment (PPE).
In case of any conditions that pose a risk to the safety and well being of workers, employees must report to their supervisor or file a complaint with OSHA.
Responsibly exercise the rights given to them under the OSH Act.

par.span: The OSH Act resulted in the establishment of both The National Institute
for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA).
NIOSH was established to ensure safe and healthful working conditions by:

ul.li: Gathering information;
Conducting scientific research;
Translating the knowledge gained to create relevant products and services; and
Providing training in the field of occupational safety and health.

par.span: NIOSH makes recommendations to OSHA, based on its research findings; regarding the creation or revision of OSHA standards.
Congress enacted a number of legislative acts in order to deal with the problems and threats posed by the industrial hazardous waste. These include:

ul.li: Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA):The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) which was passed in 1976. The main goal of RCRA was to create a "cradle to grave" system for the recordkeeping of hazardous wastes. Under this the RCRA hazardous wastes must be tracked from the time they are generated until they are finally disposed of off on-site or off-site.

Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA):The Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA), was passed by the congress in 1980. CERCLA regulates and enforces the clean-up and remediation of closed and abandoned hazardous waste sites.

SARA:The Superfund Amendments and Reauthorization Act (SARA) of 1986 amended CERCLA. This Act stressed the importance of permanent remedies and innovative treatment technologies for cleaning up of hazardous waste sites and increased the focus on human health problems caused by hazardous waste sites.

topics.name: Application of the HAZWOPER Standard to Chemical Spills

par.span: In order to get a better understanding of how the various sections of the HAZWOPER Standard apply to various groups;
let us apply this standard to chemical spills. There are two types of chemical spills:

ul.li: Incidental release:These are simply cleaned-up.
Uncontrolled release:This type requires an emergency response effort and requires workers to be trained as responders.

par.span: The response effort is termed as “Emergency Response Phase”. The clean-up phase that follows an emergency response is called the “Post-Emergency Response Cleanup Operation”.
The next slide will illustrate the types of chemical spills and the application of the HAZWOPER Standard to these spills.

par.span: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) establishes workplace standards related to health and safety for various occupations.
To protect the health and safety of employees who deal directly with hazardous waste in their daily work
OSHA requires a 40-hour HAZWOPER training. This HAZWOPER certification must be renewed every year with an 8-hour refresher course.
The HAZWOPER training is required for anyone who is cleaning up hazardous waste sites,
working with hazardous waste at treatment, storage or disposal (TSD) sites, or responding to emergencies concerning the release of hazardous materials.

par.span: HAZARD COMMUNICATION
Chemicals directly or indirectly affect our daily lives, impacting our food, health and lifestyle.
While chemicals can be helpful in many ways, they can also have serious and sometimes deadly impacts on human health and the environment.
For example, chemicals can cause heart diseases, burns and rashes, kidney and lung damage, sterility, cancer and many more deadly side effects.
Due to the possibility of severe injury, it is important to have readily available information on the hazardous properties of chemicals and recommended control measures.

This is the purpose of OSHA’s Hazard Communication Standard, or HCS. It requires employers to provide workers with information and identities of workplace chemicals to help them make smart decisions about chemical hazards to which they are exposed.
The HCS ensures that all chemicals produced, imported, or used by American companies are evaluated, and the information is communicated to workers
Information on the Hazard Communication Standard can be found in OSHA regulation 29 CFR Part 1910.1200.
The Hazard Communication Standard requires that employers provide employees with information through:

ul.li: A written program for each location to cover chemical safety, hazard communication and safe work procedures;
Labelling containers of hazardous chemicals;
Safety Data Sheets (SDSs) which provide detailed information about a hazardous chemical; and
Training employees on labelling and SDSs information.

par.span: Some substances are not covered by HCS because they fall under the jurisdiction of regulations
other than OSHA’s Hazard Communication Standard 29 CFR Part 1910.1200.
The chemicals not included under HCS are:

ul.li: Hazardous wastes defined by RCRA
Any hazardous substance defined by CERCLA
Tobacco products
Wood products
Food or alcoholic beverages
Drugs
Cosmetics
Ionizing and non-ionizing radiation
Biological hazards

par.span: In 2012, OSHA modified the HCS to fall in line with the United Nations’ Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labeling of Chemicals,
also known as GHS. The GHS is a system used to harmonize and standardize the classification and labeling of chemicals.
It is a comprehensive approach for determining health, physical, and environmental hazards of chemicals. This system is updated every two years to keep it current.

The main objective of this system is for the same set of rules for classifying hazards, and the same format and content for labels and safety data sheets (SDSs) to be be adopted and used around the world.
Thus, increasing the quality and consistency of information provided to workers, employers and chemical users. GHS went partially into effect in 2012, and was fully effective by June 1, 2016.

A very important benefit that came from aligning OSHA’s HCS with the international GHS is that now every chemical imported into the United States is accompanied by easily understandable hazard and precaution information.

topics.name: Which substances are covered by the GHS?

par.span: The GHS regulations covers only hazardous chemicals. During the classification process, the manufacturer or importer must determine whether the chemical is hazardous or not.
With the alignment of GHS to HCS, the hazard information became consistent in format making it easier to understand for both the employees and the employers.
GHS simply communicates the inherent risks of chemicals, and each country can implement its own chemical controls.
The GHS has explicit criteria for the classification of hazardous chemicals which help determine both physical and health hazards. All these hazards will be discussed in detail in later lessons.
In order to stay safe, workers must receive training from their employers, and they should always use safe handling procedures, read labels, and check SDSs.
When OSHA modified its Hazard Communications Standard to align with the Globally Harmonized System, several key revisions to the HCS happened:

ul.li: Permissible exposure limit (PEL), threshold limit value (TLV) and carcinogen status for hazardous chemicals were to be disclosed.
A new category was created that is Hazards Not Otherwise Classified (HNOC). These are disclosed on the Safety Data Sheets, not via a label.
Pyrophoric gases, simple asphyxiant, and combustible dusts are no longer listed as hazards not otherwise classified (HNOC), but are instead discussed individually.
Chemical mixtures for which data is not available, allows for educated guesses to be made based on similar mixes concerning the health hazards they pose to the exposed workers.

par.span: These changes are aimed at improving the quality and consistency in classification and labelling of chemicals allowing workers to avoid injuries and remain safe.
One way of conveying specific information about a chemical to workers is via a HAZCOM label. Chemical manufacturers and importers
must create labels based on the classification of that particular chemical and make sure they are clearly displayed on each product.
Labels contain important information, and workers should make sure to read them before beginning any work around workplace chemicals.
Labels under GHS are substantially different from other systems, such as Hazardous Materials Identification System (HMIS) and National Fire Protection Association (NFPA).
For example under the NFPA and HMIS systems, “0” was least hazardous and “4” was most hazardous. Under the GHS severity ratings, “4” is least hazardous and “1” is most hazardous.
In 2012, OSHA adopted new hazardous material labeling requirements to fall into line with the Globally Harmonized System (GHS).
Under this system, all hazardous chemicals shipped after June 1, 2015 must be clearly labeled in English with the following elements:

ul.li: A product identifier, which is the chemical name, common name, trade name, or other designation;
Pictograms, which are graphics, or pictures, that quickly give information about the chemical;
A signal word, such as “Danger” or “Warning”, to indicate the level of caution that should be used with that particular chemical or mix;
Hazard statements, which describe the type of potential hazard, such as, “Causes damage to kidneys when absorbed through the skin;”
Precautionary statements, which describe measures that should be taken to minimize the impact of the chemical, such as, “If skin irritation occurs, seek medical help;” and
Name, address and telephone number of the manufacturer, importer, or any other responsible party.

par.span: Pictograms are black pictures on a white background, surrounded by a red square frame set on the point.
The graphic representation on the next slide shows the symbol, name and associated hazards for each pictogram. GHS uses nine pictograms to communicate hazard information:
However, HCS does not include “environmental hazard”, since environmental issues fall outside OSHA’s scope.
These nine types of pictograms may have different categories, so it’s possible you may see a flame pictogram with a signal word “Danger” on one canister,
and a flame pictogram with a signal word “Warning” on another canister. This would indicate the same type of hazard in the two materials, but at different levels of severity.
In addition to the labeling changes that happened when OSHA aligned their HCS and GHS standards,
there were also important changes to data sheets that manufacturers or importers have to supply about their product. We’ll look at those now.
Under GHS guidelines, OSHA documents that were formerly known as Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDSs) became known as Safety Data Sheets (SDSs).
These are informational sheets provided by chemical manufacturers or importers to employers.
Employers must have an SDSs for every hazardous chemical on hand. The primary use of SDSs is to inform employees of potential risks from exposure to the chemical.
The SDSs include information about the properties of each chemical; the physical and health hazards; protective measures and safety procedures for handling, storing and transporting the chemical.
There are 16 categories on a Safety Data Sheet, and GHS required all SDSs be in this uniform format by June 1, 2016.
Furthermore, the format of the Safety Data Sheet was changed to put the information more immediately important to employees at the top, with the more technical information in later sections.
The information contained in the SDSs is largely similar to the older MSDSs; however now the SDSs are required to be presented in a consistent 16-section format.
This ensures that the SDSs are easy to read and ‘user friendly’ for workers, to help them better understand the nature of the chemical they’re handling.
Under the new, GHS Safety Data Sheet format, there are 12 mandatory sections, in addition to four non-mandatory sections.
The four sections that are not required to be filled out concern ecological, transport, disposal, and regulatory information.
To summarize, the following are the sections of the SDSs:

ul.li: Sections 1-8 of a Safety Data Sheet cover general information about the chemical; the name, hazards, composition, safe handling practices, and emergency control measures.

For example, here you will find information about how to put out a fire caused by the chemical, and how to prevent dangerous exposure. In short, these early sections of the SDSs contain information for workers who handle the chemical.

Sections 9-11 and section 16 contain technical and scientific information about the chemical; its properties, stability and reactivity, toxicological information, and exposure control. These sections also indicate when the report was written or last revised.

Sections 12-15 are the non-mandatory sections about environmental, transport, disposal, and regulatory issues. The SDSs must contain these sections to be consistent with the requirements of GHS; however OSHA will not enforce them as these issues fall under the jurisdiction of other agencies.

par.span: Employers must make sure that Safety Data Sheets are easily accessible by workers at all times for all the hazardous chemicals in their workplace.
SDSs must be kept in a central location, such as in a binder or on a computer - as long as employees have access to the computer
during their shift without leaving their station and there is a back-up available in case of a power outage or emergency.
As new information becomes available, the SDSs must be updated so workers always have easy access to current information.
It is the responsibility of the employer to designate a person for maintaining the SDSs.

Employees have the right to know the potential hazards of chemicals they work with at their job through SDSs, training and a written hazard communication plan.
Employers must establish a training program for employees that provides training upon initial employment,
as well as training when a new chemical is introduced into the work environment or whenever there is a change in procedure in the workplace.
Since chemicals have the potential to cause serious injury or death, OSHA created a Hazard Communication Standard, or HCS, to keep workers safe.
This supported the “Right to Know” Law, which states that employees have a right to know details about the hazardous materials they handle.
In 2012, OSHA aligned its HCS with the international Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labeling of Chemicals (GHS).

To bring HCS in line with GHS, important changes were made to labeling and Safety Data Sheets. OSHA’s Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDSs) were changed to Safety Data Sheets (SDSs) under this new system.
There must be SDSs for each chemical at a work site, and the forms must be in a central location that workers can easily access.
Finally, workers must receive training when they start work, and at any time a new chemical is introduced into the work environment.
